Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is dispatched to a patient who has fallen and broken their arm, requiring basic pain management and stabilization.
Story:
I stood in the hallway, my phone buzzing in my pocket. My mother’s voice echoed from the living room, reminding me that it was almost time for the family ceremony. This year, I was expected to lead the ritual—an honor and a responsibility, especially since my grandfather had passed. My family looked to me to uphold our traditions, to show respect and continuity. I could see my father setting up the altar, my little sister watching me with wide, hopeful eyes.

Then my radio crackled. Dispatch called: a woman had fallen, possibly a broken arm, pain severe. I was the closest ambulance driver on shift. My training kicked in—stabilize, manage pain, reassure the patient. I knew someone was waiting for me, scared and in pain, depending on my skills and calm.

I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family needed me to honor our past; a stranger needed me to protect their present. My heart pounded as I stared at the ceremonial robe in my hands, the ambulance keys in my pocket, torn between two urgent calls, each demanding all of me.
